Definition: People who are 15 to 39 years of age.
A lab test of any molecule in your body that can be measured to assess your health. Also called molecular testing.
A procedure that removes fluid or tissue samples to be tested for a disease.
The structures within cells that contain coded instructions for cell behavior.
A type of research that assesses health tests or treatments.
A mix of sperm and fluids. Also called semen.
The ability to produce children.
A way to preserve or protect the ability to become pregnant and have a baby.
Coded instructions in cells for making new cells and controlling how cells behave.
An abnormal change in the coded instructions within cells.
A doctor who’s an expert in reproductive cancers of those assigned female at birth.
A chemical in the body that triggers a response from cells or organs.
A mutation passed on from parent to a child that is present before birth.
Procedure that removes eggs from the ovaries and combines them with sperm for fertilization in a lab.
A doctor who treats cancer in adults using systemic therapy.
The end of menstrual periods.
An abnormal change in the instructions within cells for making and controlling cells.
Cancer doctors and reproductive experts who work together to help people keep their ability to have babies.
A doctor who’s an expert in the treatment of cancer.
The process of freezing one or more unfertilized eggs (eggs that have not been combined with sperm) to save them for future use. Also called egg banking, egg cryopreservation, and egg freezing.
Methods used to lower hormone levels made by the ovaries.
One of a pair of glands that produce eggs and hormones. There is one ovary on each side of the uterus.
A doctor who’s an expert in testing cells and tissue to find disease.
The pattern and outcome of a disease.
Having to do with the mental, emotional, social, and spiritual aspects.
Support given to help meet the mental, emotional, social, and spiritual needs. Types of psychosocial support include counseling, education, group support, and spiritual support.
A doctor who’s an expert in treating cancer with radiation.
A treatment that uses high-energy radiation from x-rays, gamma rays, neutrons, protons, and other sources to kill cancer cells and shrink tumors.
The return of cancer after a cancer-free period.
A cancer that does not improve with treatment.
The return or worsening of cancer after a period of improvement.
The group of organs that work together to make a baby. They include the vagina, cervix, uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries, penis, testicles, and prostate.
The fluid that is released through the penis during orgasm. Semen is made up of sperm from the testicles and fluid from the prostate and other sex glands. Also called ejaculate.
An unhealthy or unpleasant physical or emotional response to treatment.
Cell formed in the testicle.
A procedure in which a sample of sperm cells is removed from the testicle through a small needle attached to a syringe.

The process of freezing sperm and storing it for future use. Samples of semen are collected and checked under a microscope in the laboratory to count sperm cells and find out how healthy they are. The sperm cells are then frozen and stored. Also called sperm cryopreservation.
A count of the number of sperm in a sample of semen. A sperm count may be used as a measure of fertility.
A cancer treatment that replaces abnormal blood stem cells with healthy cells. Also called hematopoietic cell transplant (HCT) or bone marrow transplant (BMT).
Three-dimensional conformal radiation therapy.
A cancer of cells that line organs and make fluids or hormones.
Treatment that is given after the main treatment to prevent the cancer from returning.
The tiny sacs in the lungs where gases are transferred in and out of the blood.
A status for doctors who finished training and passed exams in a specialized field of medicine.
A test of how much air is in your lungs after inhaling or exhaling.
Small airways within the lungs.
A device that is guided down the throat to look inside the airways.
A procedure to look inside the airways with a device that is guided down the throat.
One of the two main airways that extends into the lungs.
Routine testing for cancer in people without symptoms.
A rating of the outlook of a cancer based on its growth and spread.
A cancer of cells that line the inner or outer surfaces of the body.
A lab test of the amount of 8 chemicals in a sample of blood. Also called metabolic panel.
A combined treatment with both chemotherapy and immunotherapy.
A cancer treatment with both cell-killing drugs and high-energy rays.
Treatment with cancer drugs that kill fast-growing cells.
The layer of muscle, bone, and fat that protects the vital organs.
Lung damage or too much mucus that makes breathing hard.
The rating of the extent of cancer before treatment is started.
A lab test that measures the parts of the blood.
A test that uses x-rays from many angles to make a picture of the insides of the body.
A substance put into your body to make clearer pictures during imaging.
An identification of an illness based on tests.
A procedure that takes detailed pictures inside the body with a device guided down the windpipe.
A procedure that takes detailed pictures inside the body with a device guided down the throat.
The tube-shaped organ between the mouth and stomach.
Radiation therapy received from a machine outside the body.
Food and Drug Administration.
Fluorodeoxyglucose.
A test that makes a video of the inside of your body.
A test that uses harmless gas to measure how much you breathe out.
A drug treatment that helps the body's immune system find and destroy cancer cells.
Treatment with radiation that uses small beams of different strengths.
The growth of cancer from where it started into another type of tissue.
A cancer of lung cells that lack features to classify as another type of lung cancer.
A clearly seen division in an organ.
An operation that removes a whole lobe of an organ.
A test that uses small amounts of radiation to make pictures of the insides of the body.
A small, bean-shaped, disease-fighting structure.
A test that uses radio waves and powerful magnets to make pictures of the insides of the body.
A procedure to do work in the chest with a device passed through a small cut in the skin.
The area of the chest between the lungs.
A report of all your health events and medications.
The spread of cancer from the first tumor to a new site.
A procedure to do work in the smallest airways with a device guided down the windpipe.
National Comprehensive Cancer Network.
A cancer treatment that is given before the main treatment.
A small mass of tissue.
A cancer that starts in lung cells that are not small.
A small tissue mass of low density.
A small tissue mass with areas of low and high density.
A rating of the extent of cancer based on tests given after treatment.
A review of the body by a health expert for signs of disease.
An operation that removes the entire lung.
A test that uses radioactive material to see the shape and function of body parts.
A test that uses two picture-making methods to show the shape and function of tissue.
The main mass of a certain type of cancer cell.
Radiation therapy that uses protons to treat a disease. Also called hadron therapy.
A set of breathing tests to test the strength of the lungs.
A doctor who’s an expert in lung diseases.
A procedure to do work inside the lung with an imaging device guided down the windpipe.
The group of organs that transfers gases in and out of the body.
A method to perform a surgery called thoracoscopy.
Rapid on-site evaluation.
An operation that removes a large part of a lobe.
An operation to remove an entire lobe and part of the bronchus.
A cancer of small lung cells.
A small mass of tissue of high density.
A test that uses a tube to measure how fast you breathe.
A type of cancer of thin and flat cells that line the surface of organs.
Treatment with high-dose radiation within one or a few sessions. Also called SBRT.
A mass of cancer cells that starts at the top of the lung and easily grows into the chest wall.
Cancer care that includes symptom relief but not cancer treatment. Also sometimes called palliative care.
An operation to remove or repair a part of the body.
The normal-looking tissue around a tumor that was removed during an operation.
Interventions to improve the health and well-being of people who have or had cancer.
A doctor who’s an expert in reading imaging tests of the chest.
A drug treatment that impedes the growth process specific to cancer cells.
A doctor who’s an expert in operating on organs inside the chest.
A treatment with radiation that uses beams matched to the shape of the tumor.
A procedure that removes tissue samples with a thin needle guided through the ribs.
A test that uses sound waves to take pictures of the inside of the body.
An operation that removes a small part of a lobe.
Treatment that is given after surgery to lower the chances of the cancer returning.
A small organ on top of each kidney that makes hormones.
A cancer that grows or spreads fast.
An abnormal response by the body to a foreign substance that is harmless.
The opening of the intestinal tract between the legs through which stool passes out of the body.
A small tube-like organ attached to the first section of the large intestine.
A test to measure the level of chemicals in the body.
A term used for the airways that lead to the lungs (bronchi and pulmonary).
A rating of how much cancer cells look like normal cells.
A group of symptoms that happen when carcinoid tumors release serotonin and other chemicals into the blood.
A neuroendocrine tumor found most commonly in the gastrointestinal tract, lungs, bronchi, thymus, and other areas in the body. It may secrete the hormone serotonin and other chemicals.
The hollow organ in which eaten food turns from a liquid into a solid form.
A hormone that controls blood sugar, metabolism, and other functions in the body.
A condition caused by the release of excess cortisol in the body.
A chain of chemicals in cells that contains coded instructions for making and controlling cells. Also called the “blueprint of life.”
A part of the digestive tract that receives food from the stomach and mixes it with digestive juices.
A device that is passed through a natural opening to do work inside the body.
Removal of an organ or tumor in such a way that it comes out clean and whole, like a nut from its shell.
The first drug or set of drugs given to treat cancer.
A hormone made and released by the stomach.
The group of organs through which food passes after being eaten. Also called digestive tract.
A lab test (usually performed on blood or saliva) to identify abnormal genes that impact your risk of developing cancer.
A hormone made by the pancreas that works with insulin to control blood sugar levels.
Passed down from parent to child through coded information in cells.
A skin rash caused by the body trying to rid itself of a foreign substance.
A part of the brain that works with the nervous system and glands that make hormones in the body.
The last section of the small intestine.
A test that makes pictures (images) of the insides of the body.
The body’s natural defense against infection and disease.
A chemical that controls the amount of sugar in the blood. It lowers the blood sugar levels.
The middle section of the small intestine.
The largest organ and gland in the body with many vital functions.
One of a pair of organs that consists of airways and air sacs.
An inherited syndrome that causes tumors to grow in the glands of the endocrine system.
A treatment given before the main treatment to reduce the amount of cancer. Also called preoperative treatment if given before an operation.
A cell that receives signals from the nervous system to make and release hormones into the blood.
A tumor that starts in neuroendocrine cells.
A period of testing for changes in cancer status while not receiving treatment.
Health care that includes symptom relief but not cancer treatment. Also sometimes called supportive care.
An organ that makes fluids that help digest food and hormones that control blood sugar.
The body area between the hipbones.
A procedure that uses a radiopharmaceutical drug to target and treat certain neuroendocrine tumors.
A small gland in the cerebrum of the brain.
An organ in the brain that controls certain body functions and other hormone glands. Also called the 'master gland'.
The main treatment used to rid the body of cancer.
The growth or spread of cancer after being tested or treated.
A male gland that makes fluid that protects sperm from the acid in the vagina.
A treatment that uses high-energy rays or related approaches to kill cancer cells.
A drug that carries a certain amount of radioactive material.
An organ that holds stool until expelled from the body.
A hormone that sends signals between nerve cells and controls things like mood, sleep, and memory.
A peptide hormone that attaches to receptors and controls the endocrine system and nervous system.
A type of imaging scan used to assess carcinoid tumors that have somatostatin receptors.
An organ of the digestive system that turns solid food into a more liquid form.
One of a pair of egg-shaped glands found inside the sac between the legs of a man.
A gland that is behind the breastbone.
A substance found in body tissue or fluid that may be a sign of cancer.
A sore on the skin or mucous membrane in the body.
A hormone that controls the amount of water and minerals absorbed into the small intestine during digestion.
A test that uses small amounts of radiation to make pictures of the insides of the body. Also called a plain radiograph.
American Joint Committee on Cancer.
Any molecule in your body that can be measured to assess your health.
A treatment phase using one or more first-line drugs to prolong good treatment results.
A procedure that removes tissue samples with a hollow needle. Also called core biopsy.
Deoxyribonucleic acid.
Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group.
A coded instruction within a cell that is made from parts of other coded instructions.
A special lab test done on a tissue sample.
A treatment phase that is given to prolong good treatment results.
Not otherwise specified.
A rating of one’s ability to do daily activities.
A procedure that removes fluid from around the heart with a needle.
A treatment with two cell-killing drugs, one of which contains the chemical platinum.
A size assessment of removed tissue during a medical procedure.
A cancer of small, round lung cells.
A treatment phase with a new drug that is given to prolong good treatment results.
The airway between the throat and airway into the lungs. Also called the windpipe.
Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery.
A memory device for characteristics of moles or skin lesions that might be cancer.
Cancer that has spread beyond the area near the main tumor.
A drug or other substance that causes a controlled loss of feeling or awareness with or without loss of wakefulness.
One half or side of the mole does not match the other half or side.
Treatment given to prevent, control, or relieve side effects and improve comfort and quality of life.
BRAF mutations can cause normal cells to become cancerous. They are most commonly found in melanomas but can occur in other forms of cancer.
A measure of how deep the melanoma tumor has grown into the skin.
A substance that protects the skin from the sun by blocking 2 types of harmful ultraviolet (UV) rays — UVA and UVB.
A procedure to remove the lymph nodes after a positive sentinel lymph node biopsy.
A test that uses x-rays from many angles to make a picture of the inside of the body.
A measure of how many cancer cells are growing and dividing in the dermis.
A doctor who’s an expert in skin diseases.
The second layer of skin that is beneath the top layer (epidermis).
Cancer cells have spread to a part of the body far away from the first (primary) melanoma tumor.
A long molecule that contains our unique genetic code.
The outer layer of skin.
Removal by surgery.
Surgery that removes the entire skin tumor or abnormal-looking area (lesion) to test for cancer cells.
Use of a thin needle to remove fluid or tissue from the body to be tested for disease.
Tests done after treatment to check for signs of cancer return (recurrence) or spread (metastasis).
A controlled loss of wakefulness from drugs.
A set of coded instructions in cells for making new cells and controlling how cells behave.
A method of putting fluids, including drugs, into the bloodstream.
Skin cancer spreads through a lymph vessel.
Swelling due to buildup of lymph fluid in the fatty tissue just under the skin near the surgery site.
A group of lymph nodes that receives and filters lymph that flows from a certain area of the body.
Similar to blood vessels, lymph vessels are thin-walled and tube-like but carry a fluid called lymph.
Tiny tumor deposits that have spread to lymph vessels in the skin near the first melanoma tumor and can only be seen with a microscope.
Cancer able to be removed (resected) by surgery.
Surgery to find and remove a sentinel lymph node to see if it contains cancer cells.
A treatment that gives a single large dose of radiation concentrated on a tumor, while limiting the dose to surrounding organs.
A number that indicates how well the sunscreen protects skin against sunburn.
Treatment that uses a virus to infect and kill cancer cells while avoiding normal, healthy cells.
Treatment where tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes are removed from the patient's tumor, grown in a laboratory, and given to the patient by infusion.
A break in the skin like an open sore.
A cancer treatment that replaces abnormal blood stem cells with healthy donor cells.
A cancer treatment that destroys your bone marrow then rebuilds it with your healthy stem cells. Also called high-dose therapy with autologous stem cell rescue (HDT/ASCR).

A drug that is almost an identical drug made by another company. It has been approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and must be used in the exact same way and at the same dose as the other drug.
The sponge-like tissue in the center of most bones.
A procedure that removes a liquid bone marrow sample to test for a disease.
A procedure that removes bone and solid bone marrow samples to test for a disease.
No signs of lymphoma are found. Also called complete remission.
A lab test of substances on the surface of cells to identify the type of cells present.
A lab test that uses special dyes to look for abnormal chromosomes and genes.
A doctor who’s an expert in digestive diseases.
A type of bacterium that causes inflammation and ulcers in the stomach or small intestine.
A doctor who specializes in the study of blood diseases and cancers using a microscope.
A cancer treatment that replaces abnormal blood stem cells with healthy cells.
The study of tissues and cells under a microscope.
A cell protein by which your body knows its own cells from foreign cells.
A lab test that detects the type of cells present based on the cells’ surface proteins.
The first treatment that is given to greatly reduce the amount of cancer.
Uses radiation therapy to treat cancer located in a small region or one area of your body.
Lab test that makes a map of chromosomes to find defects.
A protein in blood that helps to make energy in cells.
A clear fluid containing white blood cells.
Lymph nodes that are abnormal in size or consistency.
Germ-fighting network of tissues and organs that includes the bone marrow, spleen, thymus, lymph nodes, and lymphatic vessels. Part of the immune system.
A type of white blood cell that is part of the immune system.
Referring to a type of white blood cell called a lymphocyte.
The phase of treatment used over a long period to prevent cancer from returning.
A period of testing for changes in cancer status.
Lymphoma is still present but has reduced in size.
Blood that circulates throughout the body.
A type of blood cell that helps control bleeding. Also called thrombocyte.
A lab process in which copies of a DNA part are made.
A period of time without treatment to allow blood cell counts to return to normal.
A type of blood cell that carries oxygen from the lungs to the rest of the body. Also called an erythrocyte.
Minor or no signs of disease.
An organ that is part of the lymphatic system. The spleen makes lymphocytes, filters the blood, stores blood cells, and destroys old blood cells.
Surgery to remove the spleen.
A switching of parts between two chromosomes.
A rare condition caused when waste released by dead cells is not quickly cleared out of your body.
A type of blood cell that helps fight infections in the body. Also called a leukocyte.
The outer layer of the adrenal gland that makes androgen and corticosteroid hormones.
Surgery to remove one or both adrenal glands.
A rare type of cancer that forms in the adrenal cortex (outer layer) of the adrenal glands.
A condition that occurs due to too much aldosterone being produced by the adrenal glands. Also called primary aldosteronism or hyperaldosteronism.
A lab test of abnormal coded instructions in cells that are passed down within a family.
A condition caused by the release of excess cortisol, a hormone, in the body. Also called Cushing syndrome.
A condition in which the force of the blood against the artery walls is too high. Also referred to as high blood pressure.
Tumor that arises from neuroendocrine tissues found along the spine.
Tumor that forms in the center of the adrenal gland that causes it to make too much adrenaline.
A condition that occurs due to too much aldosterone being produced by the adrenal glands. Also called Conn syndrome or hyperaldosteronism.
Occurring at irregular intervals or only in a few places.
Prostate cancer that has spread beyond the prostate to other areas in the body, including regional and metastatic prostate cancer.
Hormone therapy that stops the body from making testosterone or blocks cancer cells from using testosterone. ADT can be given through drugs or surgery.
A drug that stops the action of the hormone testosterone.
Surgery that removes the testicles, or drugs that suppress the function of the testicles, to minimize testosterone levels.
An imaging test that uses x-rays from many angles to make a picture of the inside of the body.
An exam of the prostate by feeling it through the wall of the rectum.
Prostate cancer that stays within the prostate and usually grows slowly.
An overgrowth of tissue in the prostate that isn’t caused by cancer. Also called benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
A lack of blood flow to the penis that limits getting or staying erect.
A treatment in which a machine outside the body aims radiation precisely at cancer inside the body.
A harmful change in the cell’s instructions, which damages its function and can lead to disease.
A cancer treatment that stops the making or action of hormones. Also called androgen deprivation therapy.
The number of years a person is likely to live based on statistics of other people in similar circumstances.
A drug that acts in the brain to stop the testicles from making testosterone.
A network of organs and vessels that fights infections and transports a fluid called lymph.
Small clusters found throughout the body that filter lymph fluid to remove germs.
The spread of cancer from the site where it started to a new site in the body.
Cancer that spreads beyond the prostate to other parts of the body.
A period of watching for cancer occurrence or growth while not receiving treatment.
An operation to reduce testosterone in the body by removing one or both testicles.
Health care for the symptoms of cancer or the side effects of cancer treatment. Palliative therapy is an important part of supportive care.
A doctor who specializes in testing cells and tissue to find disease.
An operation that removes lymph nodes in the pelvis.
An imaging test that uses radioactive material to see the shape and function of body parts.
A protein made by the prostate that helps semen transport sperm. PSA is measured in nanograms per milliliter of blood (ng/mL).
A protein found on the surface of prostate cancer cells. PSMA is a biomarker of prostate cancer cells.
When PSA level is still detectable after prostate cancer treatment.
When PSA level drops after prostate cancer treatment but then rises again.
Treatment that uses high-energy rays (radiation) to kill cancer cells and stop new cancer cells from being made.
An operation that removes the entire prostate as well as surrounding tissue, seminal vesicles, and sometimes nearby lymph nodes.
The return of cancer after a disease-free period.
Cancer that has grown from the prostate to neighboring areas, but no farther.
Something that increases the chance of getting a disease.
Glands that make and store part of the fluid that becomes semen.
Health care other than curative treatment that supports the physical, emotional, social, and spiritual needs of patients, families, and caregivers.
An estimate of the body’s ability to fight infections, especially bacterial infections.
A protein made by a plasma cell (a type of white blood cell) to help fight infections.
A type of lymphocyte (white blood cell).
An immature blood cell, also called a lymphoblast.
An immature blood-forming cell from which all other types of blood cells are made, also called a hematopoietic stem cell.
A small, bean-shaped structure that fights disease.
A type of white blood cell that fights infections, especially bacterial and fungal infections.
A type of blood cell that helps control bleeding, also called a thrombocyte.
A type of blood cell that carries oxygen from the lungs to the rest of the body, also called an erythrocyte.
A type of lymphocyte.
A fast-growing cancer that causes too many immature white blood cells (lymphoblasts) to be made.
Stem cells donated by someone else, who may or may not be related to you.
Stem cells that come from your own body.
An abnormal protein made by the BCR::ABL1 fusion gene that causes too many abnormal white blood cells.
Drugs that kill fast-dividing cells, including cancer cells and normal cells.
One of the post-induction phases of cancer treatment.
The first phase of cancer treatment.
Usually the last phase of ALL treatment.
Small amounts of ALL cells that remain after treatment, detected by sensitive tests.
A condition in which bone marrow activity is decreased, resulting in fewer blood cells.
The growth or spread of cancer after testing or treatment.
Cancer that does not improve with treatment.
A treatment plan that includes drug doses, timing, and duration.
There are minor or no signs of disease.
When cancer does not respond to a drug treatment.
A smaller group within a type of cancer based on cell features.
The removal of a small amount of solid bone and bone marrow to test for disease.
The removal of a small amount of liquid bone marrow for testing.
Long strands in cells that contain genetic instructions.
A substance used in imaging tests to make pictures clearer.
The study of chromosomes.
Genetic information found in cells.
A lab test measuring chemicals made or processed by the liver.
A lab process that copies a piece of DNA.
Uses sound waves to make images of the scrotum.
A treatment replacing damaged bone marrow cells with healthy blood-forming cells.
A treatment that helps the body find and destroy cancer cells.
A method for delivering chemotherapy into the vein in a controlled manner.
A treatment that uses high-energy rays to target cancer.
A drug treatment that specifically targets and attacks cancer cells.
A drug used to reduce inflammation and kill leukemia cells.
Treatment that works throughout the body.
Symptom relief without cancer treatment.
People who are 15 to 39 years of age at the time of cancer diagnosis.
Soft tissue in the center of bones where blood cells are made.
A person who gives organs, tissues, or cells to another person.
Located outside the bone marrow.
Coded instructions in cells for making and controlling cells.
A doctor specializing in blood diseases.
A doctor who specializes in blood diseases by examining cells.
Special proteins on cells that help the body differentiate between its own and foreign cells.
A doctor specializing in cancer treatment.
A type of skin cancer that most often develops on areas of skin exposed to the sun, such as the face.
A starting point to which future test results are compared.
The edges (border) of the mole are ragged or notched.
The use of two or more drugs.
Presence or absence of cancer cells in the normal-looking tissue under a tumor removed during surgery.
An immunotherapy medicine put directly into the bladder to treat bladder cancer.
An imaging test used to view bones for cancer or other problems.
A flat area of cancer cells that hasn’t grown any farther than where it started.
A treatment given after the initial therapy kills all visible cancer. Consolidation therapy is used to treat any cancer cells left behind by previous therapy.

A type of urinary diversion in which a portion of the large intestine is used as a pouch to hold urine. A section of the small intestine connects the pouch to a hole (stoma) in the wall of the abdomen. A catheter is used to drain urine from the reservoir. Also called an Indiana pouch.
A surgical procedure that removes all or part of the bladder.
A procedure that allows a doctor to see inside the bladder using a special tool inserted through the urethra. Usually occurs in a procedure room in the doctor’s office.
A method of speeding up chemotherapy by reducing the amount of time between treatments.
The presence of blood in urine.
A type of urinary diversion in which a piece of small intestine (ileum) is used as a pipeline (conduit) for urine to leave the body through a hole (stoma) in the abdomen.
A treatment that uses a catheter to put medicine directly into the bladder.
A treatment given to a specific area or organ of the body. Examples are surgery and radiation.
Bladder cancer that has invaded the muscle layer of the bladder wall.
A type of urinary diversion in which a piece of small intestine is made into a new urinary reservoir. This is connected directly to the urethra so you can pee more normally.
Bladder cancer that hasn’t grown into the muscle layer of the bladder wall.
A surgical procedure that removes the bladder, nearby lymph nodes, and other organs in the pelvis.
A surgical procedure that removes as much cancer as possible while leaving the rest of the tissue or organ in place.
A rating of the extent of cancer in the body.
Ongoing testing after treatment ends to watch for cancer to return.
A type of treatment that works throughout the body.
A surgical procedure to remove bladder tumors through the urethra without having to cut into the abdomen.
A combination of three therapies—TURBT, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy—used to preserve the bladder in certain people with muscle-invasive bladder cancer.
A pair of tubes that carry urine from the kidneys to the bladder.
A procedure that allows a doctor to see inside the kidneys and ureters using a special tool called a ureteroscope.
A type of surgery that creates a new way for urine to leave the body after radical cystectomy.
A lab test performed on urine to detect cancer or precancerous cells.
An imaging method that creates detailed pictures of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder.
Cancer that begins in the urothelial cells that line inside of the urinary tract.
The stretchy inner lining of the bladder and other organs of the urinary tract.
Treatment with radiation to the part of the breast with cancer. It is given over a shorter period compared to whole breast radiation therapy.
A drug that stops estrogen from attaching to cells.
The darker, round area of skin on the breast around the nipple.
A drug that lowers the level of estrogen in the body.
A small, disease-fighting structure near the armpit (axilla).
An operation that removes the lymph nodes near the armpit.
Pictures of the insides of both breasts taken via x-rays.
An operation that removes both ovaries.
A drug that is nearly identical to another drug, approved by the U.S. FDA for the same usage and dosage.
A test that measures the strength of bones.
A test that takes pictures of bones to check for health problems.
An extra dose of radiation to a specific area.
A cancer treatment that involves removing a breast lump.
A small bag filled with saltwater, gel, or both, used to reconstruct breasts.
An operation that creates new breasts.
A breast examination by a health professional to feel for diseases.
A rating of the extent of cancer before starting treatment.
A procedure that removes tissue samples with a hollow needle, also known as a core biopsy.
Breast cancer that starts in the cells lining the milk ducts.
A hormone that plays a role in breast development.
A procedure that removes tissue samples with a thin needle.
Cancer cells that use hormones to grow.
A computed tomography (CT or CAT) scan uses x-rays and computer technology to take pictures of the inside of the body.
A mammogram is a picture of the inside of your breast made using x-rays to check for abnormal areas.
A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan uses radio waves and powerful magnets to take pictures of the inside of the body.
A positron emission tomography (PET) scan is a type of imaging test that helps reveal how your tissues and organs are functioning.
A cancer treatment that stops the making or action of estrogen, also called hormone therapy.
The growth of breast cancer into the breast's supporting tissue (stroma).
An operation that removes a small breast cancer tumor, also called breast-conserving surgery.
A picture of the insides of the breast made using x-rays.
An operation that removes the whole breast.
A procedure in which a small sample of tissue is removed from the breast with the aid of a vacuum device.
A method to shift breast tissue during an operation to fill a space left from a lumpectomy.
Treatment with radiation of the entire breast.
A language disorder caused by injury to the brain. A possible neurologic side effect of CAR T-cell therapy.
Having low numbers of B cells. A common and sometimes long-term side effect of CAR T-cell therapy.
The escape of fluid and proteins from blood vessels into surrounding tissues. Results in dangerously low blood pressure.
Brain swelling that causes an increase in pressure inside the skull. A possible side effect of CAR T-cell therapy.
A type of immunotherapy in which T cells (a type of immune system cell) are modified in a way that allows them to find and kill cancer cells.
A seizure lasting longer than 5 minutes, or having multiple seizures within a 5-minute period without fully recovering between them.
Inflammation-reducing medicines. They reduce the activity of the immune system. Used to treat side effects of CAR T-cell therapy.
A potentially serious side effect of CAR T-cell therapy. Caused by the release of inflammatory proteins into the blood from immune cells affected by the immunotherapy.
A mental state causing confusion, disorientation, and memory problems. May also cause agitation, hallucinations, and extreme excitement. A possible side effect of CAR T-cell therapy.
An immune system problem in which not enough antibodies are made, resulting in increased infection risk.
Low blood pressure. A possible complication of cytokine release syndrome.
Decreased oxygen reaching body tissue. A possible complication of cytokine release syndrome.

Term: immune effector cell-associated hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis-like syndrome (IEC-HS)
Definition: A serious problem in which too many of a type of white blood cell and T cells are made by the body. Previously known as macrophage activation syndrome (MAS).
A group of nervous system-related side effects of CAR T-cell therapy.
A solution made from antibodies taken from the blood of healthy donors is given through a vein. Sometimes given to prevent infections after CAR T.
The use of medicines to draw fluid out of the skull and the brain, reducing pressure. Also called hyperosmolar therapy.
A strategy to ensure that the benefits of using a drug outweigh its serious potential risks. Required by the U.S. Food & Drug Administration (FDA) for currently available CAR T-cell therapies.
Sudden, uncontrolled body movements and changes in behavior caused by abnormal electrical activity in the brain.
A prescription medicine used to treat severe or life-threatening cytokine release syndrome caused by CAR T-cell therapy.
Medicine that raises blood pressure by contracting (tightening) blood vessels. Used in emergency situations to treat severely low blood pressure.
The belly area between the chest and pelvis.
A less common type of cervical cancer that contains both squamous cells and gland-like cells.
Specific features of cancer cells. Biomarkers can include proteins made in response to the cancer and changes (mutations) in the DNA of cancer cells.
A type of radiation therapy in which radioactive material sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters is placed directly into or near a tumor. Also called internal radiation therapy.
Abnormal and potentially pre-cancerous cells on the surface of the cervix. Also called cervical dysplasia.
The lower part of the uterus that connects to the vagina.
A procedure in which a cone-shaped piece of abnormal tissue is removed from the cervix. May be used to gather more information about the extent of a cancer or to treat some early cervical cancers.
The rounded, outer part of the cervix that extends into the vagina. The ectocervix is lined with cells called squamous cells.
The inner part of the cervix that forms a canal between the vagina and the uterus. The endocervix is lined with columnar (glandular) cells that make mucus.
Surgery to remove the uterus (including the cervix). The vagina is not removed. The connective tissue and fat surrounding the cervix is not removed. Also called simple hysterectomy.
A thin tube through which an egg travels from the ovary to the uterus.
A common sexually transmitted infection. Almost all cervical cancers are caused by long-term HPV infection.
Small groups of disease-fighting cells located throughout the body.
The presence of tumor cells in the blood vessels or lymph vessels inside the tumor. LVSI is a risk factor for cancer spread.
Surgery to remove the uterus (including the cervix). A half inch or less of the vagina is also removed. Some of the connective tissue and fat surrounding the cervix is also removed.
A rare and often aggressive subtype of cervical cancer.
A nerve problem that causes pain, tingling, and numbness in the hands and feet.
Surgery that moves one or both ovaries out of the range of the radiation beam. Also called ovarian transposition.
The fat and connective tissue surrounding the uterus. The parametrium helps connect the uterus to other tissues in the pelvis.
A physical exam of the external genitalia, vagina, cervix, uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries.

A radical surgery used to treat cervical cancer that returns to the pelvis. The uterus (including the cervix), vagina, ovaries, and fallopian tubes are removed. The bladder, rectum, and/or anus may also be removed.
Treatment with two or more chemotherapy drugs and the main drug is made with platinum.
Surgery to remove the uterus (including the cervix) and the top quarter or third of the vagina. The connective tissue and fat surrounding the cervix is also removed.
A doctor who is an expert in interpreting imaging tests.
The area where the endocervix and ectocervix meet. Also called the transformation zone. Most cervical cancers and pre-cancers start in the squamo-columnar junction.
The stopping of menstrual periods caused by surgery to remove the ovaries.
Surgery to remove the cervix. The upper part of the vagina and certain pelvic lymph nodes may also be removed.
The organ where a fetus grows and develops during pregnancy. Also called the womb.
The hollow, muscular tube through which babies are born. Also called the birth canal.
A type of local therapy used to destroy tumors in the liver or lungs. Also called image-guided thermal ablation.
Cancer in cells that line organs and make fluids or hormones. The most common type of colon cancer.
The most common type of colon polyp. Most likely to form cancer cells. Also called adenomatous polyps.
Specific features of cancer cells used to guide treatment. Biomarkers are often mutations (changes) in the DNA of the cancer cells.
A chemotherapy regimen that includes capecitabine and oxaliplatin.
A protein that gets released by some tumors and can be detected in blood.
Abnormal cells on the innermost layer of the colon wall. These cells may become cancer and spread into deeper layers of the colon wall.
Surgery to remove a part of the colon.
The first and longest section of the large bowel. Unused food is turned into stool in the colon.
Insertion of a thin tool into the colon to view or remove tissue.
Surgery to connect a part of the colon to the outside of the abdomen and that allows stool to drain into a bag.
Blockage of blood flow to a tumor with beads that emit either chemotherapy or radiation.
An inherited cancer syndrome that increases the risk of colon cancer.
A chemotherapy regimen used for some advanced colon cancers. Includes leucovorin calcium, fluorouracil, and irinotecan.
A chemotherapy regimen used for some advanced colon cancers. Includes leucovorin calcium (folinic acid), fluorouracil, irinotecan, and oxaliplatin.
A chemotherapy regimen that includes leucovorin calcium, fluorouracil, and oxaliplatin.
A medical specialty that uses imaging techniques to deliver minimally invasive cancer treatments.
A long tube-shaped organ that forms the last part of the digestive system. Includes the colon, rectum, and anus.
Surgery to remove lymph nodes.
Surgery to remove cancer that has spread far from the first tumor.
A biomarker (feature) of some colon cancers that is used to guide treatment. All colon cancers should be tested for this biomarker.
Describes cancers that do not have the mismatch repair deficiency (dMMR) biomarker.
A biomarker (feature) of some colon cancers. Recommended as part of comprehensive biomarker testing for metastatic colon cancer.
An overgrowth of cells on the inner lining of the colon wall. Pedunculated polyps are shaped like mushrooms with a stalk. Sessile polyps are flat.
A minimally invasive procedure to enlarge the healthy part of the liver before a liver resection.
A specialized type of radiation therapy used to treat colon cancer that has spread to the liver, lungs, or bone.
Cancer that cannot be removed safely by surgery.
